review.title: Prediction and Clustering in Signed Networks: A Local to Global Perspective
review.abstract: The study of social networks is a burgeoning research area. However, most existing work deals with networks that simply encode whether relationships exist or not. In contrast, relationships in signed networks can be positive ("like", "trust") or negative ("dislike", "distrust"). The theory of social balance shows that signed networks tend to conform to some local patterns that, in turn, induce certain global characteristics. In this paper, we exploit both local as well as global aspects of social balance theory for two fundamental problems in the analysis of signed networks: sign prediction and clustering. Motivated by local patterns of social balance, we first propose two families of sign prediction methods: measures of social imbalance (MOIs), and supervised learning using high order cycles (HOCs). These methods predict signs of edges based on triangles and \ell-cycles for relatively small values of \ell. Interestingly, by examining measures of social imbalance, we show that the classic Katz measure, which is used widely in unsigned link prediction, actually has a balance theoretic interpretation when applied to signed networks. Furthermore, motivated by the global structure of balanced networks, we propose an effective low rank modeling approach for both sign prediction and clustering. For the low rank modeling approach, we provide theoretical performance guarantees via convex relaxations, scale it up to large problem sizes using a matrix factorization based algorithm, and provide extensive experimental validation including comparisons with local approaches. Our experimental results indicate that, by adopting a more global viewpoint of balance structure, we get significant performance and computational gains in prediction and clustering tasks on signed networks. Our work therefore highlights the usefulness of the global aspect of balance theory for the analysis of signed networks.

sections.heading: 6 Experimental Results
sections.text: We are now presenting experimental results for predicting signs and clusters using our proposed methods. To predict signs, we show that local methods such as MOI and HOC provide better predictive accuracy when longer cycles are taken into account. Furthermore, if we take into account the global structure of the low-ranking network, prediction by matrix factorization outperforms local methods both in terms of accuracy and runtime. For clusters, we show that low-ranking clusters deliver better results than clusters across signed Lapland. These results point to the usefulness of the global perspective of social equilibrium.

sections.heading: 7 Related Work
sections.text: They defined balanced triads and examined the global structure of balanced signed networks and showed that poorly balanced graphics exhibit mutually antagonistic groups as a global structure. Although theoretical studies on signed networks have been conducted for a long time, it was only in this decade that the analysis of real signed networks could be carried out on a large scale as large real networks, and showed that poorly balanced graphics have recently become more accessible. Thus, Kunegis performed several analysis tasks on Slashdot, and Leskovec et al. [2010a] investigated the local and global structure of three real signed networks. They designed several computer-based experiments to justify that the structure of these signed networks correspond to some widely used social theories.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we examined the usefulness of social equilibrium to significant networks, with two basic applications: character prediction and clustering. Starting from a local view of social equilibrium, we proposed two families of character prediction methods based on local triads and cycles: prediction of measures of social imbalance (MOIs) and supervised learning based on high order cycles (HOCs). For both approaches, prediction accuracy is improved when longer cycles are taken into account, suggesting that a broader view of local patterns helps in predicting signs. We then looked at the fully global perspective of social equilibrium and showed that the ad jazz matrices of balanced networks have a low rank. Based on this observation, we modelled the sign prediction problem as a low matrix completion problem. We discussed three approaches to matrix completion projection: matrix completion, contextual and relaxation.

metadata.abstractText: The study of social networks is a burgeoning research area. However, most existing work deals with networks that simply encode whether relationships exist or not. In contrast, relationships in signed networks can be positive (“like”, “trust”) or negative (“dislike”, “distrust”). The theory of social balance shows that signed networks tend to conform to some local patterns that, in turn, induce certain global characteristics. In this paper, we exploit both local as well as global aspects of social balance theory for two fundamental problems in the analysis of signed networks: sign prediction and clustering. Motivated by local patterns of social balance, we first propose two families of sign prediction methods: measures of social imbalance (MOIs), and supervised learning using high order cycles (HOCs). These methods predict signs of edges based on triangles and l-cycles for relatively small values of l. Interestingly, by examining measures of social imbalance, we show that the classic Katz measure, which is used widely in unsigned link prediction, actually has a balance theoretic interpretation when applied to signed networks. Furthermore, motivated by the global structure of balanced networks, we propose an effective low rank modeling approach for both sign prediction and clustering. For the low rank modeling approach, we provide theoretical performance guarantees via convex relaxations, scale it up to large problem sizes using a matrix factorization based algorithm, and provide extensive experimental validation including comparisons with local approaches. Our experimental results indicate that, by adopting a more global viewpoint of balance structure, we get significant performance and computational gains in prediction and clustering tasks on signed networks. Our work therefore highlights the usefulness of the global aspect of balance theory for the analysis of signed networks.
